Czech[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • kurs

Etymology[edit]

Latin curro

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): [ˈkurs]
  • audio
    		(file)

Noun[edit]

kurz m

  1. course (period of learning)
  2. course (direction of movement of a vessel)
  3. rate (in exchange rate)

Derived terms[edit]

  • měnový kurz
  • kurzovné
  • kurzovní

Related terms[edit]

→

  • rekurze

  • rekurzivní

  • kurz in Akademický slovník cizích slov, 1995, at prirucka.ujc.cas.cz

German[edit]

Etymology[edit]

From Middle High German kurz, from Old High German kurz, from Proto-Germanic *kurtaz, from Latin curtus. Compare also native Old High German *skurz, scurz and Middle High German schurz. Cognate with English curt.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /kʊʁt͡s/, [kʰʊɐ̯t͡s]
  • audio (Germany)
    		(file)
  • audio (Austria)
    		(file)

Adjective[edit]

kurz (comparative kürzer, superlative am kürzesten)

  1. short, brief
  2. concise

kurz

Old High German[edit]

Alternative forms[edit]

  • churt, churz, kurt

Etymology[edit]

From Proto-Germanic *kurtaz, a very late borrowing from Latin curtus, therefore forms with and without shift of -t-. Compare a similar situation in German Pforte.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /kurt͡s/

Adjective[edit]

kurz

  1. short

Derived terms[edit]

  • kurzī

Descendants[edit]

  • Middle High German: kurz, korz, kurt
    • Central Franconian: kurt, kurz, korz
    • German: kurz
    • Luxembourgish: kuerz
    • Yiddish: קורץ‎ (kurts)

Polish[edit]

Etymology[edit]

Deverbal of kurzyć. Compare Czech kouř.

Pronunciation[edit]

  • IPA(key): /kuʂ/
  • audio
    		(file)
  • Homophone: kusz

Noun[edit]

kurz m inan

  1. dust

Usage notes[edit]

There are two words that overlap semantically with English dust. The first one is kurz, which refers to airborne dust that settles on things as a form of pollution. The second is pył, which is neutral and refers to any very finely divided solid substance. For instance, the phrase I swiped the dust from the shelves would be equivalent to Starłem kurz z półek, but the compound coal dust would be translated as pył węglowy.

Declension[edit]

declension of kurz
singularplural
nominativekurzkurze
genitivekurzukurzów
dativekurzowikurzom
accusativekurzkurze
instrumentalkurzemkurzami
locativekurzukurzach
vocativekurzukurze

Related terms[edit]

  • kurzyć
  • zakurzony

Verb[edit]

kurz

  1. second-person singular imperative of kurzyć
